# Order {#def-order}

In group theory, the term **order** has two related but distinct meanings:

## Order of a Group

The **order of a group** $G$, denoted $|G|$ or $\text{ord}(G)$, is the [cardinality](../logic-set-theory/def-cardinality.qmd) of $G$:
- For finite groups: the number of elements in $G$
- For infinite groups: said to be infinite

### Examples
- $|\mathbb{Z}_n| = n$ for the cyclic group of integers modulo $n$
- $|S_n| = n!$ for the symmetric group on $n$ elements
- $|\mathbb{Z}| = \infty$ for the group of integers under addition

## Order of an Element

The **order of an element** $g$ in a group $G$, denoted $|g|$ or $\text{ord}(g)$, is the smallest positive integer $n$ such that:
$$g^n = e$$
where $e$ is the [identity element](def-identity-element.qmd) of $G$.

If no such positive integer exists, the element has **infinite order**.

### Equivalent Definition

The order of an element $g$ equals the order of the [cyclic subgroup](def-cyclic-group.qmd) generated by $g$:
$$|g| = |\langle g \rangle|$$

### Examples
- In $\mathbb{Z}_6$: $|2| = 3$ since $2 + 2 + 2 = 6 \equiv 0 \pmod{6}$
- In $(\mathbb{Z}, +)$: every non-zero element has infinite order
- In any group: $|e| = 1$ (only the identity has order 1)

## Properties

### For Groups
1. A group has order 1 if and only if it is the trivial group $\{e\}$
2. Groups of prime order are [cyclic](def-cyclic-group.qmd)
3. The order of a [subgroup](def-subgroup.qmd) divides the order of the group (see @thm-lagrange)

### For Elements
1. $g^{|g|} = e$ and $|g|$ is the smallest such positive integer
2. $g^k = e$ if and only if $|g|$ divides $k$
3. $|g^{-1}| = |g|$ (an element and its inverse have the same order)
4. If $g$ and $h$ commute, then $|gh|$ divides $\text{lcm}(|g|, |h|)$ (see @../number-theory/def-lcm)
5. Conjugate elements have the same order: $|hgh^{-1}| = |g|$

## Connection to Cyclic Groups

An element $g$ has order $n$ if and only if the cyclic subgroup $\langle g \rangle$ it generates has exactly $n$ elements:
$$\langle g \rangle = \{e, g, g^2, \ldots, g^{n-1}\}$$

A group $G$ is [cyclic](def-cyclic-group.qmd) if and only if it contains an element whose order equals $|G|$.

## See Also

- @thm-lagrange - The order of any element divides the order of the group
- @def-cyclic-group - Groups generated by a single element
- @thm-sylow - Results about subgroups of prime power order
- @def-quotient-group - The order of $G/H$ equals $[G:H]$
